message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about weather and cloud formations. Grey clouds are typically associated with rain or precipitation. When we see grey clouds in the sky, it often indicates that there is water vapor in the atmosphere, which can condense and fall as rain or other forms of precipitation. Option (A) is incorrect because grey clouds are not indicative of hot weather. Option (B) is incorrect because while electrical currents can develop within clouds, it is not the primary source or purpose of grey clouds. Option (D) is incorrect because vitamin D is obtained from sunlight, not from clouds.

When clouds are grey, it indicates that they are dense and full of water droplets or ice crystals. As a result, the clouds are a source of falling liquids, such as rain or snow. Option (A) is incorrect because grey clouds do not necessarily indicate hot weather. Option (B) is incorrect because while storms can produce electrical currents, grey clouds alone do not generate them. Option (D) is incorrect because vitamin D is primarily obtained through sunlight, not from clouds.
